--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "joel278" <lehman.154@...> wrot=
e:
>
> The results in the ALife paper compare novelty search to both fitnes=
s-based search and random search in a maze navigation domain. On a moderate=
ly-deceptive map, novelty search outperforms fitness search, and fitness se=
arch outperforms random search. On a very deceptive map, novelty search onc=
e again outperforms the other two methods, but fitness-based search is appr=
oximately equivalent to a random search.
> 
> Any form random search (such =
as the one you suggest) does not exploit any sort of domain information and=
 will likely perform very badly at almost any task if a large proportion of=
 genotypes specify degenerate behaviors (which is likely the case for real-=
world domains; most random genomes likely encode no useful information).
> =

> To understand why a search for behavioral novelty may often be much diff=
erent than a random search of the genotype space, it is helpful to consider=
 the mapping of a genotype to a behavior. This mapping is a composition of =
the mapping between genotype to phenotype and from phenotype to behavior sp=
ace. 
> 
> The first mapping (from genotype to phenotype) is the encoding. =
In neuroevolution, this encoding translates the genotype to a neural networ=
k. NEAT and HyperNEAT are two potential encodings among many.
> 
> The seco=
nd mapping (from phenotype to behavior space) maps a neural network to its =
behavior when evaluated in a domain (for example, the coordinate within the=
 maze where a navigational robot with a particular brain would navigate to)=
. 
> 
> It is important to note that for many encodings (including NEAT and=
 HyperNEAT), the space of genotypes is effectively infinite-dimensional bec=
ause of genetic operators that add genes. This allows NEAT to evolve ANNs o=
f arbitrary complexity and HyperNEAT to evolve CPPNs of arbitrary complexit=
y. 
> 
> However, the space of behaviors is typically not infinite-dimensio=
nal; for example, in the maze domain, it is only two-dimensional. So, the s=
pace of behaviors may be significantly smaller than the space of all possib=
le neural networks. 
> 
> It is also somewhat reasonable to believe that pe=
rturbing a genotype that maps to a certain behavior may often generate a si=
milar, yet slightly different behavior. In this way, it may be more effecti=
ve to explore the behavior space by perturbing genotypes representing novel=
 behaviors rather than exhaustively or randomly searching through the under=
lying genotype space.
> 
> Imagine a situation in which 99% of all genomes =
map to degenerate behaviors that do nothing, but the remaining 1% of genome=
s map to behaviors that are functional, and these 1% of genomes form a conn=
ected mesh in the search space (that is, they are reachable from each other=
 through mutations). In a random search, 99% of all evaluations will be was=
ted, while a search for novelty will exploit domain information to more eff=
ectively find these non-degenerate behaviors.
> 
> In summary, random searc=
h ignores domain information, while a search for novelty (or a fitness-base=
d search) does utilize domain information.
>
